Patch Set 14: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 34d21443ea6ac906308b17bad9606896fff3aa98
Looking good... a few questions about needed changes.

I don't fully understand how the systemd service units are configured.  I believe this file (dropbear.env) is used for ssh port 22 (which reaches BMC command shell, aka Redfish ManagerConsole).  Should the content of this file be: -G priv-admin?
I have updated the comment. Both files are used for the host console. dropbear.2200.env is used by the dropbear service and dropbear.env is used by the dropbear socket.
Why are these IBM-specific variable names?  Was that left over from unit testing?  Can be be renamed EXTRA_USERS_PARAMS to be consistent with Yocto/OE?
Good catch. Done.
nit: Remove trailing space
Done

I don't have enough information to confidently say that making these changes in `meta-phosphor/` is what we actually want. Isn't the group constraint a policy owned by IBM? Why are we making these decisions for everyone else? Essentially, I'm trying to understand the justification for why we shouldn't make these changes in `meta-ibm/` instead.
I don't *think* I'm opposed to this change. Let's see how it plays out.
ok
Why are we adjusting these variables here and not in the recipes where these groups matter? `obmc-phosphor-image.bb` certainly feels like the wrong spot, regardless.
Done. Moved it to phosphor user recipes

If this is something that's to be generally deployed shouldn't we keep this script in the phosphor-user-manager repo?

Generally openbmc/openbmc should only contain bitbake metadata.

I think this is how it is done for any later changes. Even adding user is also done under this repository.

For example:
users/phosphor-user-manager_git.bb:GROUPADD_PARAM:${PN} = "priv-admin; priv-operator; priv-user "
users/phosphor-user-manager_git.bb:GROUPADD_PARAM:phosphor-ldap = "priv-admin; priv-operator; priv-user "
Generally we've been moving towards maintaining the service units in the application repo. Ideally we'd move this one into phosphor-user-manager.

right now there are no scripts in the phosphor-user-manager. Most of the user related work is done in this recipe. Also I searched for upgrade scripts and all are implemented in the openbmc repository.
This is a service unit though, and we've been migrating them into their associated repositories.
Replying to myself here, but we're calling the shell script from the service unit, so maybe we just untangle this all later.
I am assuming this is resolved for now.

This violates the [Incorrect placement of executables in /sbin, /usr/sbin or /bin, /usr/bin](https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/anti-patterns.md#incorrect-placement-of-executables-in-sbin-usrsbin-or-bin-usrbin) anti-pattern. It's not intended that users call `upgrade_hostconsole_group.sh` from a shell prompt, rather it's meant to be integrated into the user manager service unit. Executables of such nature should be placed under `/usr/libexec/<package>/`

Got it. Thanks.

Moved the executable to /usr/libexec directory.

No. Please drop this change for several reasons:

1. Everything under `poky/` comes from the upstream Yocto project. If we're changing metadata in `poky/` then the patch needs to go upstream
2. `/etc/obmc-console` holds configuration that is *specific* to `obmc-console`. `obmc-console` configuration doesn't have any place being integrated into the generic dropbear service.

So, please drop this change.

Done.

Moved this to the meta-phosphor/recipies-core.

When I meant drop this, I meant completely (not just move it from `poky/` to `meta-phosphor/`) :) The dropbear service unit is unrelated to obmc-console. obmc-console happens to use dropbear, but not via its service unit.

Configuration under `/etc/obmc-console/` does not belong in the dropbear service unit.
Comment removed by: Andrew Jeffery; Reason: Unfinished message
Done

We still need to account for `$DROPBEAR_PRIV_ARGS` here. I think this is best done by sending a patch upstream. Then we can backport that to openbmc/openbmc and not have to carry this copy of the service unit.
Can I go with making copy of the dropbear@service recipe and set the variable?

In a separate discussion we decided that we'd drop `EnvironmentFile=/etc/default/dropbear` from the obmc-console unit files, which avoids the problem altogether. We need to get the Ampere layer's service units cleaned up, but with this approach the problem with the dropbear service unit goes away entirely.
It was decided that we will make these changes in a separate drop as we also need to make changes in the Ampere recipes.
Is the `rm` necessary? The file shouldn't exist.
Done
Is the `rm` necessary? The file shouldn't exist.
Done
This is a policy decision for th meta layers depending on meta-phosphor and doesn't belong here. Please delete it.
Done
Unnecessary whitespace change. Please drop.
Done
`getent group priv-admin`?

We don't have getent command on obmc.

$ getent group priv-admin
-sh: getent: command not found
Drop this change, as per the discussion on the obmc-console patch about dropping `EnvironmentFile=/etc/default/dropbear` from the service units.
Done. Removed the /etc/default/dropbear file dependency.
This is starting to look good to me. Thanks for your persistence!
This requires the directory is already present, which is guaranteed by the `install` invocation on line 36. So you should move this below that.
Done. Thanks for the review.
From a dropbear / obmc-console perspective I'm happy with this change

After further testing this needs to be:

```
DROPBEAR_RSAKEY_DIR=/etc/dropbear
```
Done

I've fixed the bug with the dropbear RSA key directory.

Ninad: To continue working on this patch and addressing any comments from others you'll have to start a new branch with the following command:

```
git fetch ssh://amboar@gerrit.openbmc.org:29418/openbmc/openbmc refs/changes/44/62744/3 && git checkout -b change-62744 FETCH_HEAD
```

Please get in touch (e.g. on discord) if you need more information.
